comment: Young and spirity with stone fruits, citrus and malt. A splash of water helps tame the beast.

I think I love Sherry Wood more in my head than on my tongue. I’m revisiting my Westland bottles with a shard of ice and a fresh perspective. 
SW on ice stubbornly maintains its color until the 25th hour, but the nose absolutely blossoms into this rich landscape. The palate wants to open up as well but just barely doesn’t and it keeps that astringent finish that I’m too much of a baby to ignore. That said, nothing ventured, nothing gained... we’re back at the rating we started and I’m not mad at it.

I love Sherry Wood. A cousin of Peated apparently, both employ ex-sherry casks. Today brought me a buttery note I hadn’t previously noticed. 
Simple and elegant. This thing is like a wild horse. I’m not sure what I mean by that, but it sounds right. Like when you see a shiny, black horse running in slow motion so you see all the veins and striations. This sip is kinda like that.
Very fruity.  One note.  But good finish.  Lots of sweet fruits.

First opened
No water

Nose - sweet sherry, dark fruit

Taste - very fruit forward, good finish with a little burn.
A little rough unless you hold your breath.
Sweeter. Smells lakenmaple syrup, tastes heavily if Stone fruit.

I'm with palerider on this one.  Westland shows potential, but its bottlings need quite a bit more time before they might qualify for this sort of mark.  Expect metallic notes o' plenty.  Frankly, Lance's credibility has taken a serious beating with this review.
Calm down on the 96 rating, very nice indeed but very young and not better than the best out there... As this rating would have you believe
So insanely delicious! Seriously great! Tasted with a special tour granted to the Distiller team and I promptly bought some.
Good whiskey.  Smooth, sweet, caramel, fruit, but I think a 98 rating is a little over zealous-- notice that they have revised the rating to an 84
Sweet. Rich. Cherries. Very smooth. So good!

Between the richly spiced nose and the long, dry finish is a bawling toddler of a whiskey. There's huge promise in here that a few more years' maturation will no doubt reveal, but at this age the sharpness of the taste overshadows the fruity aromas and spicy, tannic finish.

This one is all dried fruits and sherried notes on the nose. It makes you think it's going to be a Sherry bomb on the palate like an Aberlour A'bunadh or Glenfarclas but then the palate is really chill. It carries the dried fruits from sherry casks along with some fig preserves and fruit cake. Finish is moderate length with tart dried fruits like dried cherries or currants.
Wow... Yummy!  There's nothing more I could add to Lance's notes that isn't already there. Highly recommend.

Throw in a splash of cold water and it's an incredible array of flavors that belie the barley and sherry casks.  Think chocolate covered espresso beans, slight oak and bananas.  Ignoring price, this is a 92-95 point dram.  More aging could yield something incredible.  Mildly overpriced at this maturity.
Much more sherry forward than the American single malt. Drier finish. Miss the nuance of the saison yeast.

The first thing that came to mind with this whiskey was white chocolate covered raisins. More chocolatey than its predecessor, with a really well-implemented frutiness, as to be expected with the aging in the sherry casks. Another really great whiskey from this distillery,. Can't recommend it highly enough.

Good vs great is always a matter of opinion, but we can at least say unique. All fo the complexity you would expect with this barrel medley! However, I'm getting a mouthful of carob and milk chocolate (think Sixlets candy) and can't get past that. Definitely a mav worth trying... Just not one to my *personal* liking.
Slightly sweet but not too mellow

In my opinion, this is a good whiskey but not a great one. I loved the nose. I smelled this for about 5 minutes before tasting because I enjoyed the nose so much. It's sweet with maple syrup, cherries, dried berries, oak and a hint of char. On first taste I was immediate let down. The overwhelming flavor and texture of the whiskey was a bitey, white pepper flavor that I was not expecting at all. After a few seconds the flavor hit in a really big way though: more dried fruits with layers of espresso and malt chocolate. The finish was medium length but the berry flavor left and it was more espresso and chocolate. All in all, I really enjoyed this but it's not a 98 in anyone's book, or it shouldn't be. I'm happy to have it on the shelf. If I could give this a 3.5 star rating I would just but I'll be honest and say that 75% of the 4 star I'm giving this is for the nose.
Just too sweet for me. I have yet to find an american single malt i like and rhis isnt itceither
Impressive for such a new distillery, excited by the American Single Malt movement and not disappointed in how this whiskey is contributing to that movement.
Tasted during at "Meet your Maker" at MWL.    I enjoyed the nose immensely with the sweet smell.  However, the taste was too subtle.
The sweetness of the malt segues into chocolate and then a long bitter cocoa finish. Dessert is served.
Great for a young whisky, but it tastes really young.

YOUNG!  Don't be fooled, this is NOT a 98/100. Buy this if you're a hipster with a tiny mason jar to drink it out of, or just spend your money on a quality whisky. It could be great in a few years, but not yet...
Big sherry nose. Light and sweet.

I think individual taste buds explain why the professional here ranked it so high (as high as the Yamazaki 18 or Highland Park 18!!) while some of us thought it has a ways to go.  My thoughts, for what it's worth...it shows potential, but it's just not there yet.  I like the nose (sweet cherries, caramel), but then it starts to fall apart a bit on the taste, and the finish is a bit bitter and stinging, quite indicative of it's youth.   For the price---so, not worth it.  I'd like to come back, maybe a few years later, when it matures a bit.  Till then, I'll save my money for the worthwhile drams instead of financing a start up with a so-so product.
Nose is sweet, honey and raisin... very much like sherry.  Flavors of chocolate and spice.  Sweet and a little nutty.  A bit light in body, but still delicious.

Overall, a nice whiskey. Honey is prominent on the nose, with a little burn. Mild sherry flavor, more honey sweetness and heat. Finish provides bitter wood and a dry smoke, and if you wait long enough chocolate and walnuts show up.
Very good esp based on how young it is. I like it better than the straight Westland.

Interesting how this one went from a ludicrously high 98 rating down to an 84.  I suppose we are all entitled to change our minds once in a while, yes?  I bought it because of that original 98 score...but I don't completely regret it.  It's quite nice as a sweetish, somewhat complex, porty spirit--albeit, it's a rather unusual tasting whiskey.  I do love the chocolate notes and the cherry-cola finish--more like a delightful dessert, really.    It will never be a "go-to" bottle, but I definitely like having it around for those times when I want something a little "different".  I'll certainly look forward to what Westland's future (and hopefully more aged) bottlings will offer.  I would rate this one in the middle of two extremes.  87/100 MMB 15-06-16
Semi sweet cherry hint of maple/honey on the nose with a bit of spice. Taste is spicy and long with a full bodied finish. A bit of a funk, maybe from the finishing barrels.

Nose - Sherry influence is definitely present along with the fact that you do get this young spirit bite, sweet dried dark stone fruits, toasted barley, hint of cocoa nibs.
Taste - Toasted barley, cocoa nibs, toasted puffed rice cakes, young spirit bite/burn, sweet dried dark cherries/prunes/raisins syrupy sweet.
Finish - Lingering cocoa nib chocolaty bittersweet, dried dark stone fruit syrupy sweet.
Score - 86/100
Final Thoughts - So the fact that this has probably only spent about 24 months in the barrel shows, but at the same time, what is there is quite tasty. I think some additional time in the barrels might help mellow out the young spirit bite a bit and mellow and mingle things together a bit more. The sherry influence is there and the pale chocolate malt they used really shines through and adds a delicious toasted chocolaty note I quite enjoy.

The first Sherry'd whiskey I liked. With no smoke influence I finally understood what sherry does to a whiskey. It's fantastic and gave me a new found love for the Macallan in my collection that I had typically passed over and didn't enjoy before this whiskey! Yum! Found at Mount Royal Bottle Shop in Duluth, March 2017, $71
smoother than the oak version with a hint of sweetness, overall the better of the Westlands
sherry note with a sweet sip and soft  heat and wood after taste
Much lighter and fruitier than the regular Westland.

This is a great whiskey.
I love the American Oak, this tastes like the American Oak with an added Sherry layer.
Personally, I like it without the Sherry.. Still a great dram though.
Prefer the American Single Malt. Not sure if I'm tasting a heavy wood influence.
Always a sucker for a sherry finish. Great with an FSG cigar
beautiful Sherry smell. nice smooth taste that lingers. kind of oily feeling left in mouth. great time in a glass
Good but can do better. Even for a young whiskey
3.75 stars. Pretty good. Similar tasting notes as American Oak but the sherry takes the place of some of the sweet fruit. Still spicy finish. Like it. Not top of my list but good.

Spicy, sweet and fruity, light tart.
Pleasant experience overall.
PS: there is one very nice note at the end, almost hidden but clearly expressed. I can't tell what it is.

Odor: 
Sweet, sherry and fruit aroma, not overpowering. 

Taste:
Starts off smooth, moving to a sweet fruity flavor. Blends well with the whiskey which burns the lips, but not the tongue. 

Finish: 
Spice that starts off weak and grows stronger with a slight oak aftertaste.

Nose:  Heavy malted barley, raisins, plums.  Warm maple and brown sugar oatmeal.  More sweetness, almost like molasses.  As a whole, it reminds me of warm oatmeal raisin cookies.  

Palate: Sweet brown sugar syrup.  Smokey cinnamon and molasses cookies again.  Damn, that is so reminiscent of warm, doughy, spiced baked goods - like pumpkin break.  A bit of spicy baking spices and rounded oak notes.

Finish:  Medium-long finish.  Mouthwatering, warm, open maltiness.  Slowly fading brown sugar sweetness.  The end is dominated by delicious oak and slight smoke.

Conclusion:  My god... I wasn't expecting this to be so good.  This has so much character, one of those whiskies you could pick out immediately in a blind test (in a good way).  Westland wanted to branch away from the Scottish way of single malts and make a defining American Single Malt.  They succeeded.  If it weren't for the hefty price tag on this, it would quickly become my everyday drinker.  I applaud Westland for what they've done here.

Sweet nose
Strong wood flavor 
Long spice
Enjoyable.  Sweet on the finish. Slightly Smokey at first.  Overpriced for what it is but enjoyable.
Sweet nose, brown sugar and a lot of grapes. Sweet flavor as well, almost overwhelmed by the sherry, but not in a bad way. Really tasty and lingers on your tongue
Wow this is good, perfect sherry smell, easy to sip. Need a bottle

Maple oatmeal raisin cookie nose

Second of the flight. Smoother than the American oak. Deeper more rich finish. Roasted apples

First, most noticeable feature is the sweet smell of raisins. Subtle taste with a bit of a medicinal finish. Fruit is the strongest flavor, most likely from the sherry casks. I almost wonder what a peated version of this would be like.

A whiskey sample provided by dthom as part of the "Whiskey Transfer Program".  This one kind of came out of left field and surprised me with how good it was.

Nose:  I've never smelled a whiskey that smells this heavily of bananas.  Brown old bananas.  Kind of liked dried banana chips.  Also raisins and figs and dates.  Heavy grain notes like corn flakes.  With the sweet notes it's almost like frosted flakes.

Taste:  The banana is there but more subdued with dried fruits like cherries, figs, and raisins taking over at the front.  Heavy caramelized sugars.  

Finish:  Still sweet but the wood notes start to stand out.  A long complex finish with oak, sandalwood, more dried fruit, and some spice.  Heavily spiced with cloves and cinnamon standing out on the finish.  Finishes very dry for such a sweet dram.

Wow I was surprised how much I enjoyed this.  Very complex and interesting.
not a heavy sherried whiskey.   pass for me
Tried this at the whisky extravaganza. Very good with notes of vanilla, berries, cherries, and spice.
Really interesting PX sherry flavors especially. A bit sweet for my taste but the sherry taste and texture is quite nice

Instant Sherry notes on the nose, which make sense. Doesn't smell overly sweet though. The flavors are balanced very well, mostly dark fruit flavors in with the wood. Tastes exactly like a different spin on their American Oak. Some spice comes in on the tail, which is just as long as their flagship label.
Nice malty dram with oak and sherry throughout.
Tasted during distillery tour on 11/16/19. Best of 4 tastings. Rich flavor, not too intense. Delicious

Westland Distillery, Seattle, WA. 

Flight - 2 of 4

Nose: sweet toasted wheat bread, cherry and plum, candied orange peel
Taste: brilliant dark fruit into spicy oak with a dry grain sweetness underneath 
Finish: long and spicy that doesn’t lose a fruit note

Nose: Sweet, fruit, sharp
Palate: Vanilla, sweet, tart
Finish: medium

I don't get the sherry...
Maple syrup on nose, crisp apple, little spike at end

Didn’t wow me. I appreciate what they’re doing, but there are better and cheaper options. 
Sweet to the nose. Touch of sweetness and burn, some spice, but nothing that made me want more.

Honey on the nose
Creamy and smooth
Good spicy finish
Nose is slightly ethanolly raisan characteristics. Sweet candy floss, caramel and mild px and olorosso sherry. Aftertaste is a bit bitter and stringent. Definitely comes across as younger. 3.25.
